proof:
Let us consider an arbitrary configuration $F \in B_1$. As established in Case 0 of the proof of Lemma 53, the number of components in $(V_c, F)$ that consist of a single vertex is no more than $(1 - \frac{2\eta}{3})n$. We will define $S$ to be the set of vertices that are part of components with a size of at least 2.

Observe that all endpoints of the edges in $F$ must lie within $S$, and therefore $|F| \le e_G(S)$. By combining Lemmas 29, 30 (setting $R$ to be the value $k$ from that lemma), and 35, we find that for any sufficiently large $d$, it holds with high probability that for every connected subset $S' \subseteq S$ of $(V_c, F)$, the inequality $e_G(S') \le |S'|(1+\max(1, d\eta/3))$ is satisfied. From this, it follows that $e_G(S) \le |S|(2+d\eta/3)$. Because we have $e_G(S) \ge |F| \ge \frac{9\eta}{10}|E_c|$, it must be the case that $|S| \ge \frac{9\eta|E_c|}{10d(\eta/3+2/d)}$. Since every component involving vertices from $S$ contains at least 2 vertices, the total number of components is $c(F) \le n - |S| + |S|/2 = n - |S|/2$. Consequently, we can establish the following bound:
$$
\frac{w_G(F)}{w_G(\emptyset)} = q^{c(F)-n_c}(e^\beta-1)^{|F|} \le q^{n-\frac{|S|}{2}-n_c}(e^\beta-1)^{|F|} \le q^{n-\frac{9\eta|E_c|}{20d(\eta/3+2/d)}-n_c}(e^\beta-1)^{|F|} \le q^{-\frac{9\eta|E_c|}{10d}(\frac{1}{2(\eta/3+2/d)}-21)}
$$
Here, the last inequality is derived from the condition $\beta \le \beta_1$ and the fact that, with high probability, $n_c \ge n(1-e^{-d/3})$. For any sufficiently large $d$, the term $\frac{9}{2(\eta/3+2/d)}-21$ is greater than 1. By applying Lemma 39, we know that with high probability, $|E_c| \ge \frac{dn}{2}-2ne^{-d/3} \ge \frac{dn}{3}$. This leads to the inequality $\frac{w_G(F)}{Z_c^{\mathrm{dis}}} \le q^{-n[\eta/20-e^{-d/3}]}$. For all sufficiently large $d$, this value is at most $q^{-n\eta/30}$. Finally, by summing over the at most $2^{|E_c|} \le 2^{dn}$ possible configurations for $F$, we conclude that for all sufficiently large $q$, $\pi_c^{\mathrm{dis}}(B_1) \le e^{-\Omega(n)}$.
